Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Combining Field Data and Computational Models to Characterize the Distribution of Oceanic Transform Fault Deformation throughout the Lithosphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to quantify deformation across oceanic transform faults, which are places where two tectonic plates slide past each other. Because oceanic plates are difficult to study directly, the research portion of this proposal focuses on three field sites in New Caledonia, Cyprus, and Iceland where oceanic transforms are exposed on land. These sites were chosen because they also record transform deformation from different levels (mantle, mid-crust, and upper crust) of oceanic plates. Two techniques will be used to study each transform system: the collection of detailed field measurements and the development of quantitative models based on the field data. Both are common ways to examine transform fault deformation, although they are rarely used in tandem. Comparing field data to model results will be a feedback process, to refine model set-ups and explore which kinds of parameters are important for matching field observations. Ultimately, the results from all three sites will be synthesized to better understand the plate-scale patterns of transform fault deformation.

In addition to the research objectives of this study, the educational components of this CAREER project involve two age groups of students: college students from Carleton College and 13-to 15-year old girls from Northfield, Minnesota. The Carleton undergraduate students will be involved directly in research projects, forming interdisciplinary science teams for the structural analysis and modeling of each field site. The geology majors will complete field-based projects for senior theses, and other STEM students will be recruited for summer research experiences involving computational and modeling projects. A desired outcome of the project will be that STEM students will recognize geoscience as a possible career path following college. The middle-school students will participate in a summer program that will examine, among other topics, a local example of a transform fault that is part of the Midcontinent Rift system. Although the fault cannot be observed directly, it can be imaged using geophysical methods. The objective of this summer program is to increase the interest of young girls in the geosciences, and more broadly, in science in general. Overall, the project supports the research and educational program of an early career scientist, and contributes to the research infrastructure of undergraduate institution. Research results will be broadly disseminated in the peer reviewed scientific and education literature and by presentations at professional society meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Earth's outer layers are composed of tectonic plates, and many of the societal impacts of geology --- earthquakes, volcanoes, mining, etc. --- are affected by our understanding of how these plates interact. The goal of this project was to look at how one type of plate-bounding fault, called a transform fault, affects rocks at different depths within an oceanic plate. Because oceanic plates are difficult to study underwater, we used three field locations where these types of rocks are fortuitously exposed on the Earth's surface: Rocks in New Caledonia preserve the deepest level of an oceanic plate called the mantle, rocks in Cyprus preserve the mid-crustal levels, and rocks in northern Iceland preserve the uppermost level of the crust.

We used different tools to study rock deformation in these field areas. In New Caledonia, observations at the microscopic scale revealed interesting features in the rocks that help explain how stresses are transmitted from the crust to the mantle during an earthquake along a transform fault. In Cyprus and Iceland, we collected new field and rock magnetic data sets over several field seasons focused on looking at changes in deformation as a function of distance from the transform fault. In the course of analyzing these data sets, we developed new statistical tools to look for spatial patterns (Fig. 1). These statistical tools are freely available to other geoscientists and we have led three workshops at national meetings to present these methods. We continue to work to analyze the field data from all three sites using numerical models.

Part of the broader impacts for this grant included training and mentoring undergraduate students. To achieve this goal, undergraduate students have been involved in all aspects of this research from field work to data analysis (as part of courses and senior theses) to modeling. Students in two Geophysics courses have analyzed data from Iceland as part of class research projects. A total of 19 undergraduates have written senior theses or had research projects about data and models of these field sites including 7 geology majors and 12 math/stats majors. Additionally, three post-graduate students have worked on data sets or numerical models during the year following their graduation, in a program that is akin to a mini-Masters project. We have presented the work in 26 abstracts, of which 11 included undergraduate co-authors. We have published four manuscripts with another in review.

Another part of the broader impacts for this grant was to develop a field-based experience for middle school girls to help them appreciate the geosciences (Figs. 2-6). This summer camp, called GALS for Girls' Adventures in Learning Science, ran for three summers and was staffed by four undergraduate geology majors (all women) during each iteration. Analysis of the program by outside evaluators demonstrated that it was a positive experience for participants and staff members, which also gave the staff confidence in their own teaching abilities.
